titleStmt.title: Thomas Pennant to John Lloyd, Hafodunos and Wigfair, 5 May 1795

physDesc.additions: Endorsement (in pencil on dorse, possibly in an archivist's hand): Mr. Pennant - 1795 -

div.p: Permit me to say that few gentlemen merit more frm yr country than yourself & Mr Cloughs,This is a reference to the brothers Thomas and Roger Clough. & I do most sincerely congratulate you on having brought it unlucky business to so good a conclusion.Pennant refers to anti-militia and navy-impressment riots which took place in Denbigh on 1 April 1795. See W. Lloyd Davies, ‘The Riot at Denbigh, 1795’, BBCS, IV, part I (1927), 61–73. I should rather have thought that the bench of Justices would have voted the three Gentlemen who bore the burden of their business their due thanks, instead of suffering so many gross & seditious aspersions to be uttered against their conduct. I am certain you never wd have been the instrument of oppression. You acted under an act constitutionally sanctified by the three estates of the kingdom, & proposed most cogently for the salvation of the whole. enough of this.

Now let me request you to lend to me as soon as possible Mrs Piozzi's Synonyms. I wish much to see them for the sake of some pedegree remarks on the Mostyn family. Be so good as to convey them here. I wd send for them; but a Gent: of yr volatility may be be 20 miles distant.

You are called the Philosopher. I really think I may be yr second. Pray think whether a man condemned to 9 weeks recumbency & bein it with spirit & the full persuit of literary amusements does not deserve to share the title.Pennant had broken his kneepan on 6 April 1795 according to his letter of 13 April 1795 to Richard Bull (1184). come over for an hour & see if I speak too boastingly. Adeu
